title: Missionaries and Africans in the Making of Colonial Knowledge in Belgian Congo
abstractText:
The project will examine the role of missionaries and African agents in the development of social anthropology and construction of ethnicity through a case study on the Luba-speaking peoples of Belgian Congo.  Research will centre on W.F.P Burton, a leading ethnographer from the Congo Evangelistic Mission.  It will reconstruct his ethnographic process, examining how the various contexts in which he worked shaped his writing.

The research has 5 key aims:

  1. To contribute to theories of ethnic construction by considering the agency of missionaries and African Christians;
  2. To nuance work on cultural encounter by exploring how the discipline of Social Anthropology was shaped by interactions between Africans and missionary ethnographers;
  3. To re-locate missionaries within the historiography of African Christianity and shed new light on the changing nature of the 20th Century missionary enterprise;
  4. To provide a non-hagiographical historical account of Pentecostalism, an important but hitherto neglected strand of African Christianity;
  5. To innovate methodologically in the writing of African historiography.  By combining a range of sources - artefacts, documents and interviews, - different types of knowledge - colonial, African, missionary - the research will explore the mutually constitutive nature of discourses of identity in colonial Africa.
